description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for a non-commercial car, pickup truck, RV, or van with 15 or fewer passenger seats. This fee covers the vehicle and everyone inside of it.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for a non-commercial motorcycle (cost is per motorcycle, not person).
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for people entering on foot, a bicycle, a horse, or a non-commercial bus or van. People 15 years and younger are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person, not to exceed $105. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. People 15 years and younger are free
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: An educational fee waiver is available for educational and scientific groups that are accredited or tax-exempt for educational purposes planning a trip for educational or scientific purposes related to Yosemite that is not primarily recreational.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person, not to exceed $105. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yosemite for 12 months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

directionsInfo: You can drive to Yosemite year-round and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from approximately November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow. Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Yosemite National Park

operatingHours.description: Hetch Hetchy area is only open during the day (except for permitted backpackers). All day visitors must exit Hetch Hetchy by the closure time.
operatingHours.name: Hetch Hetchy

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.altText: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring

images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.title: Glen Aulin
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.title: Half Dome
images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan and reflection in Merced River with some low clouds
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

images.title: View of Yosemite Valley in Winter
images.altText: El Capitan on left, Cathedral Rocks on the right, all covered in snow, low clouds and sun
images.caption: A rewarding view of Yosemite Valley in winter as seen from Tunnel View.

weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
name: Yosemite
